awd_titl_txt: Multi-scale modeling of multiphase flows and fluid-structure interactions in the lung
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET - 1706801
PI: Gaver, Donald P.

Mechanical ventilation is a common therapy in serious lung disorders.  While it can help sustain pulmonary function, mechanical ventilation can also induce lung injury by imposing large mechanical stresses on fragile pulmonary tissues. Therefore, developing protocols that optimize ventilator performance while minimizing the risk of injury could benefit many patients who undergo mechanical ventilation.  This award will support the development of computational and experimental techniques to analyze the flow of air and liquid on the scale of individual passageways in the lung and incorporate results of those studies into models that predict overall lung performance during mechanical ventilation.  The predictive tools developed in this project could provide a foundation for a personalized medical approach toward safe mechanical ventilation.  In addition, the project will provide educational activities for K-12 students and opportunities for other students, especially those from underrepresented groups, at all academic levels to participate in the research.

A variety of lung ailments involve abnormalities in the fluid that lines passageways through the lung.  A computationally efficient, reduced-dimension, multi-scale model will be developed to dynamically simulate heterogeneous lung inflation and deflation by incorporating multiphase flows and fluid-structure interactions between liquid and tissue components.  The model will simulate an anatomically based model of the lung, including tissue and liquid components.  New experiments will be conducted to analyze multiphase flow in fluid-lined channels including such phenomena as airway closure, viscous fluid plug motion and propagation, and airway reopening, including effects of dynamic surface tension and other physicochemical interactions.  Results from these experiments and previous ones will be combined with theoretical models into an organ-level model of the lung.  Large-scale simulations of multi-scale and macro-scale phenomena in the lung under normal and disease states will be conducted to generate predictions that can be compared with well-established physiological measurements.   Results of the project will not only provide a tool to predict ventilator performance, but also could lead to new predictive insights into lung function.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE ADMINISTRATORS OF TULANE EDUCATIONAL FUND

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project developed new computer models to study the entire lung from the small to largest scales, and investigate its response to diseases and treatments. These models incorporate the complete geometry of airways and alveoli (the gas-exchange component). Of particular importance is the inclusion of the liquid lining on the interior surface, with varying surface tension. This aspect is crucial in diseases like COVID-19, which causes acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Even before the emergence of COVID-19, ARDS affected nearly 200,000 individuals annually in the US alone, with a mortality rate of 40%. ARDS is not a lifestyle condition; instead, it arises from insults such as bacterial infection (sepsis), liquid aspiration, or inhalation of noxious gases. A hallmark of ARDS is the presence of fluid-filled lungs with high surface tension interfaces. ARDS affects individuals in the prime of their lives; however, despite the high mortality rate, those who recover often return to their pre-disease levels of vitality and productivity. That's why understanding this disease is crucial because, with proper treatment, lives can be saved.

The problem is that the lung is incredibly complicated. Our new models can incorporate realistic airway geometry, including the inclusion of alveolar acini (which resemble a foam), interactions between acini, their support for the airways, the flow of air in the lungs, and the behavior of liquid and surface tension—crucial factors in disease. To complete these models and simulations, we created simplified equations that link together to describe how the lung 'breathes' under various conditions. This process involved solving thousands of equations with about one million degrees of freedom.

 

Scientific Impact:

Our research findings have been accepted by the scientific community, elucidating an understanding of lung physiology. The inaugural paper, published in Frontiers of Physiology, detailed the intricacies of a healthy lung, setting the stage for our subsequent explorations. Our investigations into the biological responses to mechanical stresses were published in journals such as Biosensors, the Annals of Biomedical Engineering, and the Journal of Applied Physiology. Finally, a pivotal paper unraveling the complexities of a diseased lung afflicted with Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) was published in Frontiers of Network Physiology. This study of healthy and diseased states contributes to the complete understanding of respiratory physiology, offering insights for future studies and potential therapeutic interventions.

In addition to papers to the scientific community, we have written papers that are focused on clinical care so that our studies can have an impact on disease treatment. These papers have been published in the American Journal of Respiratory and Critical Care Medicine, and Critical Care Medicine.

Broader Impacts:

In addition to the scientific progress, this project has had a substantial broader impact through training opportunities. We have trained two PhD students, two MS students, and at least ten undergraduates through studies related to this project. Furthermore, it has facilitated demonstrations and active learning exercises for K-12 students, aiming to provide them with insight into the exciting future that awaits in STEM fields.


Last Modified: 11/07/2023
Modified by: Donald P Gaver
